entry.title: Re: 2 org structure in SAP Business by Design
entry.content:
Based on SAP Business ByDesign (ByD) system behavior and standard organizational management principles, please consider the following points:

  1. Parallel Active Org Structures
    In SAP ByDesign, it is technically possible to maintain multiple org structures with different validity periods. The system allows you to keep the existing structure active until 31.12.2025 and activate a new structure starting 01.01.2026. Both structures can coexist in the system, but only one structure is active for any given date. That means ByD will automatically use the correct structure based on the posting date.
  2. Mid-Year Introduction of a New Org Structure
    Creating a new org structure in the middle of the fiscal year is supported. However, you must ensure that all work centers, org units, responsibilities, and financial assignments are valid from the correct dates to avoid posting inconsistencies.
  3. Closing Books Without Migrating Balances to the New Structure
    Yes, the customer can close the books for 2025 using the existing structure without migrating balances into the new structure. Since the new structure becomes valid only from 01.01.2026, the system will automatically continue to use the old structure for all postings up to 31.12.2025.

    Important considerations:

    1. No historical balances need to be migrated from the old structure to the new one, as ByD reports always respect the org structure valid for each posting date.
    2. If the customer expects comparative reporting across the two structures, this will not be possible without historical realignment (which ByD does not support).
    3. All master data assignments (profit centers, cost centers, org units) must be reviewed to ensure posting consistency from 01.01.2026 onward.
    4. Recommendation
      It is advisable to:
      • Finalize and activate the new structure well before 01.01.2026.
      • Run test postings in a test tenant to confirm reporting behavior.
      • Ensure financial reporting teams understand that reports before 2026 will reflect the old structure and cannot be retroactively mapped to the new one.

entry.title: Master Your KPIs: How SAP Revenue Growth Management Boosts Data-Driven Growth
entry.content:
1. Fragmented KPIs in Consumer Products: The Silent Threat to Revenue Growth

For IT admins and data teams in the consumer products industry, Key Performance Indicator (KPI) management is a silent battlefield. Imagine this: Your North American team calculates "profit" using distributor rebates, while Asia-Pacific excludes freight costs. KAMs waste time reconciling numbers from spreadsheets instead of analyzing performance, while IT struggles with hard-coded logic in legacy systems that turn even simple changes into slow and costly tasks. Trade finance must reconcile promotion performance across regions because volume means shipped units in Europe but sell-through in Brazil.

This fragmentation obscures strategic insights: Which promotions actually moved the needle? Did we overfund a low-potential retailer? Without unified KPI Management, growth is too often guesswork.

 

2. SAP Revenue Growth Management: The Control Tower for Your Key Performance Indicators

SAP Revenue Growth Management directly addresses these challenges with a centralized, cloud-native approach to KPI management. By embedding a unified KPI framework directly into the platform, we ensure that every user—from the IT admin configuring metrics to the KAM tracking performance—operates from a single source of truth. This eliminates discrepancies between systems, streamlines configuration, and provides clarity and confidence in the data that drives revenue growth decisions. For more information on our current capabilities, see An Overview of SAP Revenue Growth Management.

3. Key Functionalities of KPI Management in SAP Revenue Growth Management

3.1. Accelerate Time-to-Value with Preset, Industry-Built KPIs

SAP Revenue Growth Management ships with 68+ preset KPIs distilled from decades of CPG expertise, spanning planning KPIs and sales actual KPIs, including KPI’s like Gross Sales Value (GSV), Net Invoice Value (NIV), Trade Spend Rate, and more. This foundation allows teams to move quickly from implementation to insight.

  • Rapid Deployment with Proven Metrics

Instead of building a KPI library from scratch, your team can activate a comprehensive set of proven metrics on day one. This significantly reduces the initial configuration burden on IT.

  • Launch Smarter, Not Harder

For smaller CP companies, the preset set is often sufficient; for larger ones, it becomes a stable, reliable base to extend from. KAMs and finance teams immediately see familiar, relevant KPIs in account plans and dashboards, minimizing the learning curve and accelerating user adoption.

Overall, teams are better equipped to drive revenue growth with a focus on using data—not hunting for it.

 

3.2. Customize Metrics to Your Strategy: Gain Flexibility Without Fragmentation

While preset KPIs provide a strong starting point, we recognize that different retailers, sales channels, and regions have unique needs. SAP Revenue Growth Management’s KPI Profiles offer the flexibility to tailor metrics without introducing inconsistency.

  • KPI Profiles: Adapt Metrics and Calculations to Your Unique Business Needs

With KPI Profiles, you can group relevant KPIs together, define their calculation rules, and make them available for assignment to specific business contexts, such as account plans or promotions. For example, you can create a "North America Supermarket" profile for one sales area and an "Asia-Pacific Wholesale" profile for another, each with a distinct set of KPIs. This ensures that KAMs managing those specific sales areas see the metrics most relevant to their market dynamics and goals.

Beyond selecting KPIs, you can modify their formulas within a KPI Profile to match your business logic. For instance, if your company has a unique way of calculating Net Invoice Value that includes retailer-specific discounts, you can adjust the formula accordingly. This customization is safely contained within the specific KPI Profile, so edits to Profile B won’t break Profile A. When a European team tweaks Trade Rate, their U.S. peers are unaffected.

  • Determination Rules: Configure Precision

Once KPI Profiles are activated, KPI determination rules then control where and when each profile applies—for example, by validity period, sales organization, distribution channel, division, or account plans. For example, a determination rule can be set to automatically apply a specific "High-Volume Promotions" KPI profile to all account plans for a key retailer in the North-West region in the US during the peak Q4 sales period. At runtime, the system automatically picks the right KPI Profile based on these rules, so KAMs always get the correct calculations without having to manage configurations themselves.

In practice, KPI Profiles and determination rules give you the flexibility to reflect market realities and customer strategies, all within the consistency and control of a centralized KPI framework.

 

3.3. Centralized Governance and Consistency: One Truth, Everywhere

The true power of KPI management in SAP Revenue Growth Management is its role as the central governing engine for metrics across the entire application.

  • Centralized Configuration, Universal Consistency

KPIs are defined and managed in one place: the KPI Configuration within the Business Configurations. Once a KPI is established, it is automatically consumed everywhere—in Account Plans, promotion management, and Embedded Analytics dashboards. This means the "Planned Volume" a KAM sees when building a promotion is calculated using the exact same logic as the "Actual Volume" reported in the post-event analysis P&L statement.

  • A Foundation for Scalable Growth

This unified framework is designed to scale with your business. It replaces the fragile, hard-coded customizations of the past with a configurable architecture. As your business evolves and new reporting needs emerge, the system can adapt without requiring complex IT projects, ensuring your KPI strategy can support your long-term growth.

Ultimately, SAP Revenue Growth Management turns KPIs into a governed, reusable asset—so every team works from one version of the truth, even as your business and analytics needs to grow more complex.

 

4. Co-Innovation: Shape the Future of KPI Management with Us

SAP Revenue Growth Management is continuously evolving to meet the complex needs of the consumer products industry. We invite you to join our co-innovation program to get early access to upcoming capabilities and collaborate with our product team.

Help us pioneer new features, such as:

  • Promotion-Level KPI Profiles: Extend the power of KPI profiles to the promotion level, enabling even more granular and accurate post-event analysis.
  • Custom Data Point Integration: Bring additional data points from outside the core SAP Revenue Growth Management system—such as specific logistics fees or retailer-specific discounts—into your KPI calculations for a more complete picture of promotion performance.

Contact us today to start a conversation. Email us at RGM_Engage@sap.com to share your KPI management challenges and help us build the next generation of revenue growth excellence together.

 

More Information

Documentation on SAP Help Portal

Topic Page for SAP Revenue Growth Management

    • Introducing Calendar View in SAP Revenue Growth Management: A Visual Leap for Strategic Planning
    • Decoding Promotional Success: Embedded Analytics in SAP Revenue Growth Management
    • Unlocking Trade Spend Control Efficiency with Funds Management in SAP Revenue Growth Management
    • Consolidating Customer Planning: Unleash Growth with SAP Revenue Growth Management’s Account Plan
    • Elevate Your Promotion Strategy: Baseline Management with SAP Revenue Growth Management 
    • Driving Promotion Excellence: Streamlined Creation and Copying with SAP Revenue Growth Management
    • Financial Execution & Claims for Trade Promotions with SAP Revenue Growth Management & SAP Cloud ERP

entry.title: SAP CAP Lessons Learned: Reject error message missing on HTML5 Repository app?
entry.content:
Good day fellow CAPpers,

Today I'll share one of the lessons I've learned working with CAP, something that may not be clear in the current tutorials or documentation. When running locally, or even in BTP on a Cloud Foundry-based front end, whenever you reject a request, you would expect that the message appears to the user:

The top bold message is in the front end SAPUI5 app, and the bottom, the description, comes from CAP, in the req.reject call:

try {
  const con = await cds.connect.to('SERVICE_SRV');
  let entry;
  // ...
  const result = await con.run(
    INSERT.into(EntitySet).entries(entry)
   );
} catch (err) {
   req.reject(500, err.message);
}

This executes as expected on CAP, both locally and on BTP. However, in the front end, the message is only displayed locally, not on BTP if the app is deployed on the HTML5 Application Repository:

 This gave me a big headache, especially because a few weeks earlier it was displaying fine, whereas now the message is lost and replaced for "Internal Server Error".

I even debugged remotely the CAP app running on BTP to double check, and the error message was correctly set there, on the req.reject statement.

Finally, I resorted and opened a case (ticket, incident) for SAP. After providing the required test code, they gave me a solution: replace the 500 code for 400.

I chose 500 because out of the HTTP response status codes, 500 is for server errors. Since the error message I wanted to display was on the server side, I opted for 500. But apparently, you should always stick to 400 (client error) to make it work.

SAP failed to provide me an explanation to this behavior of the HTML5 Application Repository, and its behavior is like of a black box, where we can't see what's happening inside.

 

TLDR

Therefore, whenever you want to reject a request in CAP AND send the error message to the user with the details of the error AND you have deployed your app in the HTML5 Repo, use HTTP code 400.

 

May this post help you on your troubleshooting. Reply if you find any issues so I, and the community, can help.

Lucas Magrini Rigo

entry.title: Capture Correlation-ID in Joule
entry.content:
Capture Correlation-ID in Joule

Use the steps below to capture the Correlation ID in Joule, which is required for troubleshooting and providing details to the SAP Support team.

Step 1: Log in to SuccessFactors using the Chrome browser.

 

Step 2: Right-click and select Inspect.

 

 

Step 3: In Developer Tools, go to the Network tab.

 

 




Step 4: Launch Joule and enter the use case. In the Developer Tools, you will see the flower brackets. Select the latest log, which appears at the bottom, and click on it.

 

 

 

Step 5: You will see the Headers. Click on it, and at the bottom you can find the X-Correlation ID.

entry.title: Link and correlation between BOI's and API's, differences in functionality and testing tools
entry.content:
Hi all,

We are developing in a S/4 Public Cloud environment (using embedded steampunk or ABAP cloud).

As part of the developments ahead, we need to "rebuild" classic developments, which use commonly known BAPIs such as BAPI_GOODSMVT_CREATE, which are not allowed in Public cloud, based on clean core principles.

As we move forward in research of the new ways, we found out (based on the Material Document example):

- There's a Material Document Business Object: Material Document

- There's a Material Document Business Object Interface (BOI), which is intended to be used for LOCAL (embedded) RAP developments as the ones we need: MaterialDocument / I_MATERIALDOCUMENTTP

- There's a Material Document API, which is intended to be used for SIDE-BY-SIDE (from BTP) or consumed from OUTSIDE S/4 (not the majority of our current scenarios): API_MATERIAL_DOCUMENT_SRV

We also found out, while both are present and documented on Business Accelerator Hub, the API one is far more documented and friendly for a functional analyst, including even a Try-Out section to test it with data. Which is very useful as it is needed to elaborate functional specs including test cases.

This poses a problem since what we will end up using from ABAP code (by EML) is the BOI, not the API. Some people already posted in regards to this, having problems because they are not in sync in functionality or capabilities: https://community.sap.com/t5/technology-q-a/functional-differences-between-boi-s-and-api-s/qaq-p/13879790 https://community.sap.com/t5/technology-q-a/how-to-call-public-cloud-sap-api-from-embedded-steampunk/qaq-p/13725569

In analogy to the classic approach, the analyst was able to test the BAPIs from SE37 with data, and even save test cases to be used by reference for the developer.

Since we have no similar tool for BOIs, how we can assure and correlate the API and the BOI? Is there a 1:1 equivalence listing? Are there any plans for a BOI testing tool similar to the one provided for APIs?

Thank you!

entry.title: Re: Yield/Remaining Quantity Calculation with BAPI_PRODOR...
entry.content:
Dear @lou_ ,

Please find my comments to your last query, regarding your query:  

- For Order XXX, operation XX is fully confirmed, with the status marked as CNF. No additional confirmations are expected for this order.  
- For Order XXX, operation YY is partially confirmed, with the status marked as PCNF. Additional confirmations are expected for this order.  

For this reason, BAPI_PRODORDCONF_GET_TT_PROP provides a different result.

This distinction explains why BAPI_PRODORDCONF_GET_TT_PROP provides different results. Additionally, please note that CO11N will propose the confirmed yield from the previous confirmation, while the BAPI proposes the entire quantity when the status is PCNF. 

For more details in please refer to SAP note 0000359730 - Documentation on BAPI_PRODORDCONF_GET_TT_PROP

Regards

entry.title: Re: Mapping of Lump Sum Target
entry.content: Thank you for your answer! I am using standard guidelines, all ok. My problem is that the target for lump sum that is set in UDF is not populating in the worksheets. I just went for a custom MDF instead, cause I simply cannot understand how to bring it from UDF.

entry.title: Re: Mapping of Lump Sum Target
entry.content: Sounds like that is your problem - the UDF values are only used in non-EC integrated templates or hybrid templates. However, an employees data in a hybrid situation can only come from a single source. If an employee is in EC then all of their data must come from EC whereas if perhaps a certain part of the company is not yet live in EC then all of their data must come from the UDF. You cannot mix and match. So it sounds like while you uploaded data into the UDF for the target, it's not being used as your employees are Employee Central. So you need to map your Lump Sum Target field to a value that comes from EC if this is the method you are choosing to use.

entry.title: Re: CDS View in SAP Public Cloud for Settlement Rule in W...
entry.content:
Dear @gunadharshini,

In Public Cloud there is no released standard CDS view / public API that exposes the WBS settlement rule details. The classic settlement rule tables like COBRA/COBRB are not released, so you typically can’t read the settlement receivers for a WBS via a standard released CDS the way you could Private Cloud

More detail from SAP Community:

https://community.sap.com/t5/enterprise-resource-planning-q-a/cds-views-for-cobra-amp-cobrb-tables-related-to-settlement-rules/qaq-p/13994340

https://community.sap.com/t5/enterprise-resource-planning-q-a/set-automatic-settlement-rule-on-wbs/qaq-p/12363765

Best-practice logic to check AUC already exists for your goal is check:

1. Identify the WBS / project element (from Enterprise Project API as needed)

    • Example endpoint from SAP Note
      /sap/opu/odata/SAP/API_ENTERPRISE_PROJECT_SRV;v=0002/A_EnterpriseProject
      SAP also explicitly references using this Enterprise Project API in Public Cloud

SAP Note below:

https://userapps.support.sap.com/sap/support/knowledge/en/3519774

https://userapps.support.sap.com/sap/support/knowledge/en/3442752

2. Query Asset Accounting for an asset assignment where WBS element is filled

    • SAP asset assignment model includes WBS element as an account assignment attribute

3. If you find at least one matching asset, then AUC exists (optionally tighten: only accept assets of your AUC asset class/type).

More details below:

https://help.sap.com/docs/SAP_S4HANA_CLOUD/5bcca49998834de2b5533c36602e52a2/70b4b54e61634c33af065a694f30fc48.html

https://help.sap.com/docs/SAP_S4HANA_CLOUD/3e5fcf2c768746049b5627bd5a42f720/894dbc43f6d34a7aaf23d5fed6794aad.html

Best Regards,

Dawid

entry.title: Re: Selling raw material planned for production.
entry.content:
Good day @Jakobstrom 

Thank you for your question.

Have a look at the following references.

Integration into Other Processes, Fixed Pegging in the MRP Process.

In summary, reservations in public cloud are not created through pegging relationships in MRP. To reserve 500 PCs of raw materials only for the sales order driven pegging, while you keep the PIR-driven pegging provided for sales, you must use aATP Supply Protection. The public cloud clean-core principle requires you to define a protection object for sales orders and then assign the 500 PCs protected quantity. Doing that will allow the system to reserve supply for sales orders without splitting orders, while it keeps the forecast quantity available.

I will also like to draw your attention to this Blog: Increasing Reliability with Supply Protection

 

Let me know if you have further questions.

 

Best regards

Chris

entry.title: Building a Clean REST API for SAP PP Production Confirmation Using Pure ABAP OOP
entry.content:
Building a Clean REST API for SAP PP Production Confirmation Using Pure ABAP OOP (Open Source Template Included)

Author: Waruna Lakshantha
GitHub Repository

📌Introduction

Production Order Confirmation is one of the most common integration points between SAP PP and external systems such as:

  • MES (Manufacturing Execution Systems)

  • Mobile shop-floor applications

  • IoT/PDC devices

  • Operator kiosks

  • Edge gateways collecting real-time production data

Traditionally, developers implement this using:

  • RFC-enabled custom Z-Functions

  • BDC programs

  • SEGW-based OData services

  • Monolithic function modules with UI-dependent logic

These patterns work, but they come with a cost:

  • ❌Code becomes tightly coupled

  • ❌Difficult to test & debug

  • ❌Not reusable across other modules

  • ❌Hard to standardize

  • ❌Not aligned with modern integration principles (REST/JSON)

So I developed an open-source, reusable template using pure ABAP OOP + SICF REST + JSON — and published it on GitHub for the SAP community.

🚀Why a REST API Instead of RFC / SEGW OData?

1️⃣Lightweight and Simple

Unlike SEGW OData (with MPC/DPC classes, annotations, and metadata), a REST endpoint needs:

  • 1 handler class

  • 1 application class

  • 1 BAPI adapter class

  • 1 JSON helper

  • 1 exception class

That’s it.

2️⃣JSON is the universal language

Every MES / mobile / automation system can work with simple JSON payloads:

{
  "confirmations": [
    {
      "order_number": "100001",
      "operation_number": "0010",
      "yield_quantity": 120
    }
  ]
}

No XML, no SOAP, no complex metadata layers.

3️⃣Decoupled Architecture

The design follows Clean ABAP principles:

  • REST handler → handles HTTP protocol

  • Application service → validation, orchestration

  • BAPI adapter → all interaction with SAP logic

  • DTO interface → no global variables

  • Mapper → JSON ↔ ABAP separation

Perfect for real manufacturing IT architectures.

🧱 Overall Architecture

SICF Service (REST)
      ↓
HTTP Handler Class
      ↓
Application Service
      ↓
BAPI Adapter (BAPI_PRODORDCONF_*)
      ↓
SAP PP Confirmation

This is the same layered architecture found in modern backend development (.NET, Spring Boot, Node.js), applied cleanly to ABAP.

📦Open Source Repository

👉GitHub Repo

The repository includes:

Object Description

ZCL_PP_CONF_HTTP_HANDLERSICF REST handler
ZCL_PP_CONF_APPLICATIONBusiness logic / orchestration
ZCL_PP_CONF_BAPI_ADAPTERClean wrapper for PP confirmation BAPIs
ZCL_PP_CONF_JSON_HELPERJSON serialization/deserialization
ZIF_PP_CONF_TYPESDTO definitions
ZCX_PP_CONF_ERRORCustom exception class

Every class is documented and designed for reuse.

📥Sample Request (POST JSON)

POST /sap/bc/zpp_conf_rest
Content-Type: application/json
{
  "confirmations": [
    {
      "order_number": "100001",
      "operation_number": "0010",
      "plant": "1000",
      "posting_date": "2025-11-28",
      "yield_quantity": 120,
      "scrap_quantity": 2,
      "unit_of_measure": "PC",
      "confirmed_by": "PPUSER",
      "confirmation_text": "Shift A - Output"
    }
  ]
}

📤Sample Response

✔️Success

{
  "response": {
    "overallStatus": "OK",
    "results": [
      {
        "orderNumber": "100001",
        "operationNumber": "0010",
        "status": "SUCCESS",
        "confirmationId": "50001234",
        "message": "Confirmation posted successfully"
      }
    ]
  }
}

❌Error Example

{
  "response": {
    "overallStatus": "FAILED",
    "results": [
      {
        "orderNumber": "100001",
        "operationNumber": "0010",
        "status": "ERROR",
        "message": "Operation not found"
      }
    ]
  }
}

🔍Technical Highlights

✔ Stateless design (ideal for cloud/MES)

No global variables, no shared buffers.

✔ Single Responsibility Principle

Every class has a clear purpose.

✔ JSON mapping fully isolated

Easy to replace with custom or RAP-based JSON solutions.

✔ Ready for CI/CD testing

Small units mean easier unit tests and extensibility.

✔ Designed for real manufacturing fields

Tested with common PP fields: quantity, scrap, posting date, work center, etc.

🛠Installation Steps

1️⃣Import classes into SE24

(copy each .abap file)

2️⃣Create SICF service

Path example:

/sap/bc/zpp_conf_rest

Assign handler class:
👉ZCL_PP_CONF_HTTP_HANDLER

3️⃣Authorize users

Use standard SAP Basic Auth or SSO login.

4️⃣Test using Postman, VS Code Thunder Client, Insomnia, or MES system.

🌟Extensions You Can Add

You can enhance this for:

  • Time Ticket Posting

  • Goods Movements (101 / 105 / 261 / 262 / 531)

  • Serial number confirmation

  • Batch consumption

  • PDC devices

  • IoT sensor-based auto confirmations

  • Error logging into Z-tables

  • RAP-based outbound monitoring dashboard

The template is a perfect base for any inbound REST API in SAP ECC or S/4HANA.

🤝Why I’m Sharing This

Because SAP developers deserve clean, modern patterns.
And most ABAP teams still rely on RFC modules created 15–20 years ago.

If we want SAP to integrate with Industry 4.0, Smart Manufacturing, Mobile PP, and MES platforms,
we need to move toward:

  • REST

  • JSON

  • OOP

  • Clean architecture

  • Testability

  • Openness

This is my small contribution toward that direction.

🔗Links

entry.title: Boost Sales Efficiency with SAP Sales Cloud v2 Territory Management – Join Our Pilot!
entry.content:
Are you looking to enhance your sales efficiency by ensuring accurate account management while preventing coverage gaps and double ownership? If so, we have good news for you!

SAP Enterprise Support is excited to announce a new pilot offering designed to help your organization master Territory Management in SAP Sales Cloud, Version 2.

About the Pilot

The “Territory Management for Sales Employees and Administrators in SAP Sales Cloud, Version 2” pilot is an expert-guided implementation workstream that empowers customers to design, configure, and test an effective Territory Management model. Over two days, participants will gain:

  • Strategic clarity on how to structure and manage sales territories effectively
  • Technical readiness to implement and operate Territory Management within SAP Sales Cloud v2
  • Hands-on experience using their own test tenant with existing master data

This service targets both sales employees and administrators responsible for territory setup and maintenance, ensuring a seamless transition to effective territory alignment.

Who Should Participate?

This pilot is ideal for organizations that:

  • Hold a valid SAP Sales Cloud v2 license.
  • Have access to a test tenant of SAP Sales Cloud v2.
  • Maintain essential master data in the test tenant, including:
    • Accounts
    • Business users and employees
    • Sales account teams
    • Sales employee responsibilities
    • Sales territory owners
    • Opportunities
      Optionally leads, quotes, and sales orders
  • Are ready to implement the workshop learnings in their own environment post-session.

Ready to Pilot and Transform Your Sales Organization?

If your organization meets the criteria above, don’t miss this opportunity to join a new pilot service designed to maximize your investment in SAP Sales Cloud Territory Management.

Reach out today to the SAP Enterprise Support Advisory Council for detailed information and take the first step toward a streamlined, efficient sales coverage model.

We look forward to partnering with you on this exciting journey to better sales performance.

More information: short video here

Get Involved? Be part of the innovation!

  • Visit ESAC on SAP Support Portal (please note this page will be updated soon with this new workstream)
  • contact us:  esac@sap.com

entry.title: Future-Proofing SAP AMS: A Strategic Framework for 2025 & Beyond
entry.content:
Future-Proofing SAP AMS: A Strategic Framework for 2025 & Beyond

The role of Application Management Services (AMS) in SAP environments is changing faster than ever. With enterprises accelerating S/4HANA adoption, cloud modernization, and digital transformation, traditional AMS models built around ticketing and reactive support are no longer sufficient. The next generation of AMS must be predictive, intelligent, automation-driven, and closely aligned with business outcomes.

With over 18 years of SAP Basis and AMS leadership experience, I have witnessed how AMS delivery must evolve to meet the demands of 2025 and beyond. This article outlines a future-ready SAP AMS framework that integrates digital capabilities, cloud operations, AI, and business value alignment.

  1. From Reactive Support to Predictive Operations

Traditional AMS focused on resolving incidents as they came in.
Future AMS is built on:

  • Predictive and proactive monitoring
  • Real-time alerting
  • Automated diagnostics
  • Automated remediation for recurring issues
  • Pattern-based problem identification
  • Preventive maintenance based on system behavior

By transitioning to predictive AMS, organizations significantly reduce system downtime and improve operational stability.

  1. Intelligent Automation as the Core AMS Engine

Automation is fundamental to modern AMS transformation. A layered automation strategy strengthens efficiency across all support levels:

L1 Automation

  • User unlocks
  • Password resets
  • System checks
  • Basic monitoring alerts

L2 Automation

  • Transport automation
  • Database checks
  • Log analysis
  • Kernel and patch validations

 L3 Automation

  • Automated corrective scripts
  • RCA-based remediation
  • Performance optimization
  • DR validation routines

In large enterprise environments, such structured automation can reduce incident resolution time by 25-40%, enabling teams to focus on continuous improvement.

  1. Cloud-Optimized AMS for Hybrid & Multi-Cloud Environments

As organizations adopt AWS, Azure, GCP, and private cloud, AMS must include:

  • Cloud-native monitoring & observability
  • Automated scaling and resource optimization
  • Integration with SAP Cloud ALM
  • Hybrid security and connectivity
  • Cost governance and cloud financial operations
  • Blueprinting for cloud-based DR & HA

Future-proof AMS requires deep alignment with cloud-first operating models.

  1. Continuous Readiness Using SAP Activate Principles

SAP Activate is no longer just an implementation methodology, its structure can elevate AMS delivery as well.

AMS teams benefit from adopting:

  • Fit-to-standard for support process optimization
  • Sprint-based enhancements
  • Continuous testing automation
  • Controlled deployment cycles
  • Better documentation lifecycle governance

This ensures agility, transparency, and predictable quality across AMS operations.

  1. Business Value Alignment: Beyond SLA-Based AMS

Traditional AMS KPIs measured:

  • Ticket closure rates
  • SLA compliance
  • Response/resolution times

Modern AMS must move towards business-centric KPIs, such as:

  • Reduction in operational costs
  • Process cycle time improvements
  • Lower number of business disruptions
  • Acceleration of month-end closing
  • Enhanced performance of critical transactions
  • User productivity metrics

A future-proof AMS model is measured not by the number of tickets, but by how much business value it creates.

  1. Strengthening AMS with DR, HA & Cyber Resilience

With rising cyber threats and compliance needs, AMS teams must embed resilience into daily operations:

  • DR drills (automated where possible)
  • High availability validations
  • Security vulnerability management
  • Backup lifecycle automation
  • User access risk reviews
  • Zero Trust-based controls

Cyber-resilient AMS ensures business continuity in a world of increasing system risks.

  1. Building the AMS Workforce of the Future

SAP AMS roles are evolving. Successful teams now require hybrid skills across:

Technical Skills

  • SAP Basis + Cloud + Security
  • S/4HANA architecture
  • Integration (APIs, middleware)

Functional Skills

  • End-to-end process knowledge
  • Analytical and problem-solving abilities

Digital Skills

  • Automation scripting
  • AI/ML-based monitoring
  • Observability tools

The AMS workforce of 2025 is cross-skilled, automation-first, and business-oriented.

Conclusion

SAP AMS is shifting from a reactive support function to a strategic enabler of digital transformation. Organizations that adopt intelligent automation, cloud-ready operations, strong governance models, and business-aligned KPIs will achieve:

  • Higher stability
  • Lower operational costs
  • Faster innovation
  • Better user experience
  • Stronger digital outcomes

The future of AMS is not about keeping systems running ,it’s about creating continuous business value.

Thank You for Reading

Feel free to share your thoughts or your organization’s AMS transformation experiences in the comments. I look forward to engaging with the SAP Community and contributing more insights on SAP delivery, operations, and digital transformation.

entry.title: Re: Verboten?
entry.content:
Hello,

There are some SAP Notes that are intended to be available for a specific group of S-user only. There are many different reasons, like not officially released content that must have agreement, under test, etc.

It is not expected to have those SAP Notes available through the search tools. So, if you receive it from other channels than SAP development or technical support, this can be the reason for the lack of access.

Regards.
